name: Still no luck for GSK in fight against novel coronavirus
introduction: GlaxoSmithKline and Vir Biotechnology have stopped enrollment in the Phase III ACTIV trial testing VIR-7831 as a treatment for COVID-19.
content:
GlaxoSmithKline (LSE: GSK) and Vir Biotechnology (Nasdaq: VIR) have stopped enrollment in the Phase III ACTIV trial testing VIR-7831 as a treatment for COVID-19.

The decision follows an update from trial monitors indicating that, while there were no reported safety signals, the magnitude of potential benefit was unclear.

Shares in San Francisco-based Vir tumbled over a quarter following the announcement, while GSK stock was unaffected.

GSK has had a run of bad luck targeting the novel coronavirus, with delays to its vaccine program followed more recently by poor results from a Phase II study of another antibody candidate, otilimab. 

Targeting COVID-19

Vir and GSK have been working together on VIR-7831, an investigational dual-action antibody, since mid-2020.

The firms believe it has the potential to neutralize the virus, kill infected cells, provide a high barrier to resistance, and achieve high concentrations in the lungs.

As part of their work, the antibody was included in the National Institutes of Health’s (NIH)-sponsored ACTIV trial, as well as the separate Phase III COMET-ICE trial in newly-diagnosed COVID-19 patients.

Enrollment in the ACTIV trial will be stopped while the companies discuss with the NIH “appropriate ways to further assess the potential of VIR-7831 in the hospitalized population.”

GSK and Vir are still awaiting data from the COMET-ICE trial, which will give a clearer indication of whether the candidate has potential in this area.

Vir chief executive George Scangos said: “While we are disappointed with the recommendation of the DSMB, we are encouraged by the safety profile of VIR-7831 and by the possibility of a benefit on top of remdesivir and corticosteroids in this advanced cohort of patients.”

“In addition, we are eagerly anticipating the upcoming data from the Phase III COMET-ICE trial in newly-diagnosed COVID-19 patients at high risk of hospitalization,” he added.

As well as in COMET-ICE, VIR-7831 is being evaluated in the outpatient setting in BLAZE-4, a Phase II study sponsored by Eli Lilly (NYSE: LLY) testing the biologic in combination with bamlanivimab.
